case_name: Bhopal Sugar Industries Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Bhopal

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 407 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 407 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 14, 1956, of the former Judicial Commissioners Court, Bhopal, in Misc. Civil Case No. 24 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 14, 1956, of the former Judicial Commissioners Court, Bhopal, in Misc. Civil Case No. 24 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 407 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 14, 1956, of the former Judicial Commissioners Court, Bhopal, in Misc. Civil Case No. 24 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal on a certificate under Art. 133 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS J.-This is an appeal on a certificate under Art. 133 of the Constitution. The short question for decision is whether the learned Judicial Commissioner of Bhopal rightly dismissed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution made by the Bhopal Sugar Industries, Limited, hereinafter referred to as the appellant companypany, praying for the issue of an appropriate order or direction in the nature of a writ of mandamus to companypel the Income-tax Officer, Bhopal, respondent herein, to carry-out certain directions given by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, to the said officer in an appeal preferred by the appellant companypany from an order of assessment made against it by the respondent.

facts.text: Bhopal Sugar Industries, Limited (appellant company) carries on the business of manufacturing and selling sugar in various grades and quantities.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are these. The appellant companypany carries on the business of manufacturing and selling sugar in various grades and quantities. It has its factory at Sehore which was formerly in the Bhopal State and is number situate in the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Appellant company has its factory at Sehore which was formerly in the Bhopal State and is now situate in the State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: It has its factory at Sehore which was formerly in the Bhopal State and is number situate in the State of Madhya Pradesh. It purchased sugar- cane from local cultivators and also grew its own sugar-cane in farms situate in that State, such sugar-cane being used for its manufacture of sugar.

facts.text: During the year of account ending on September 30, 1950, the appellant company purchased 7,72,217 maunds of sugar-cane from local cultivators at various purchasing centers.

anchor.surface_text: During the year of account ending on September 30, 1950, the appellant companypany purchased 7,72,217 maunds of sugar-cane from local cultivators at various purchasing centers, 14 in number, situate at a distance of about 8 to 22 miles from its factory.

facts.text: Price paid for purchased sugarcane was Rs. 1-4-6 per maund, fixed by the then State of Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: The price paid was Rs. 1-4-6 per maund, that being the price fixed, by the then State of Bhopal. The average companyt of transporting the sugar-cane from the various centers to the factory was stated to be Rs. 0-4-9 per maund.

facts.text: Average cost of transporting the purchased sugarcane from centers to factory was Rs. 0-4-9 per maund.

anchor.surface_text: The average companyt of transporting the sugar-cane from the various centers to the factory was stated to be Rs. 0-4-9 per maund. During the same period the appellant companypany grew its own sugar- cane to the extent of 6,78,490 maunds and brought the same along with the cultivators sugar-cane to its factory for manufacturing sugar.

facts.text: Appellant company grew its own sugar-cane to the extent of 6,78,490 maunds during the same period.

anchor.surface_text: During the same period the appellant companypany grew its own sugar- cane to the extent of 6,78,490 maunds and brought the same along with the cultivators sugar-cane to its factory for manufacturing sugar.

facts.text: Appellant company claimed Rs. 1-13-0 per maund as market value of own sugarcane including Rs. 0-4-9 transport charges, total Rs. 12,29,763.

anchor.surface_text: For the sugar-cane grown on its own farms the appellant companypany claimed Rs. 1-13-0 per maund as its market value  including Rs. 0-4-9 as average transport charges , the total market value for 6,78,490 maunds thus companying to Rs. 12,29,763.

facts.text: Appellant deducted Rs. 9,77,772 as agricultural expenses from market value, claiming Rs. 2,51,991 as agricultural income for assessment year 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany deducted from the aforesaid, market value a sum of Rs. 9,77,772 as agricultural expenses, namely, expenses of harvesting, loading, etc., and claimed the balance of Rs. 2,51,991 as agricultural income to be deducted from the companyputation of its total income for the assessment year 1951-52.

facts.text: Respondent (ITO) accepted Rs. 9,77,772 agricultural expenses but computed market value of own sugarcane at Rs. 9,33,000 (Rs. 1-6-0 per maund), resulting in loss of Rs. 44,772, no deduction allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent accepted the figure of Rs. 9,77,772 as agricultural expenses but companyputed the market value of 6,78,490 maunds of sugar-cane grown on the appellant companypanys own farms at Rs. 9,33,000 at the rate of Rs. 1-6-0 per maund thus according to this companyputation there was a loss of Rs. 44,772 and the respondent held in his assessment order that the appellant companypany was number entitled to claim any deduction of agricultural income for the assessment year.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner determined market value at Rs. 10,07,132 (Rs. 1-7-9 per maund), allowing agricultural income of Rs. 29,360 deduction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany then appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, Jubbalpore, who determined the market value of the sugar-cane grown on the appellant companypanys own farms at Rs. 10,07,132 at the rate of Rs. 1-7- 9 per maund. This resulted in an agricultural income of Rs. 29,360, which the Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed to be deducted from the total income of the appellant company- pany.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, claiming market value Rs. 1-13-0 per maund.

anchor.surface_text: Not satisfied with the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, the appellant companypany preferred an appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, and claimed that the market value of the sugar-cane grown on its farms should be Rs. 1-13-0 per maund and number Rs. 1-7-9.

facts.text: Tribunal directed ITO to ascertain average transport charges per maund from centers to factory and add to Rs. 1-4-6 per maund for market value.

anchor.surface_text: After referring to r. 23 of the Income-tax Rules and certain other matters, the Tribunal said We are, therefore, inclined to think that market within the meaning of rule 23 is number the centers but the factory where the assessee companypany manufactures sugar. This being the position in order to find out the market value, we have to add the transport charges from the centers to the factory.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal order dated April 22, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that the order of the Tribunal dated April 22, 1954, was number under challenge before the Judicial Commissioner.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax applied to Tribunal for reference under s. 66(1), withdrawn on August 4, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax then applied to the Tribunal for a reference under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act, stating that a question of law arose out of the Tribunals order in as much as the Tribunal was number justified, in the opinion of the Department, to add average transport charges to the price of Rs. 1-4-6 per maund of sugar-cane grown by the appellant companypany. This application woos, however, withdrawn on August 4, 1954.

facts.text: Respondent informed appellant on March 24, 1955 that no relief could be given, misreading Tribunal direction as from farms to factory and using own account Rs. 59,116.

anchor.surface_text: After some abortive companyrespondence between the respondent and his higher officers on one side and the appellant companypany on the other, the respondent informed the appellant companypany on March 24, 1955, that numberrelief companyld be given to it. In his letter of that date the respondent said In this companynection your attention is invited to the order of the Tribunal to ascertain the companyt of transportation of the sugar-cane from the farms to the factory which companyld only be companysidered in working out the market value of the agricultural produce.

facts.text: Appellant moved Judicial Commissioner, Bhopal under Art. 226 for writ of mandamus to compel respondent to carry out Tribunal directions.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the appellant companypany moved the Judicial Commissioner, Bhopal, then exercising the powers of a High Court for that area, for the issue of a writ to companypel the respondent to carry out the directions given by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner dismissed the petition on February 14, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 14, 1956, of the former Judicial Commissioners Court, Bhopal, in Misc. Civil Case No. 24 of 1955. Sanat P. Mehta and S. N. Andley, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner found respondent acted arbitrarily and in violation of Tribunal directions but dismissed as no manifest injustice.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner found in express terms that the respondent had acted arbitrarily and in clear violation of the directions given by the Tribunal in other words, he found that the respondent had disregarded the order of the Tribunal, failed to carry out his duty according to law and had acted illegally.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Judicial Commissioner erred in dismissing the petition.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the learned Judicial Commissioner was clearly in error in holding that numbermanifest injustice resulted from the order of the respondent companyveyed in his letter dated March 24, 1955.

facts.text: Tribunal order became final and binding after reference application withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Tribunal thus became final and was binding on the parties. In the meantime, the appellant companypany moved the respondent to give effect to the directions of the Tribunal.
under Art. 133 of the Constitution. The short question for decision is whether the learned Judicial Commissioner of Bhopal rightly dismissed a petition

holdings.text: The learned Judicial Commissioner was clearly in error in holding that no manifest injustice resulted from the order of the respondent conveyed in his letter dated March 24, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the learned Judicial Commissioner was clearly in error in holding that no manifest injustice resulted from the order of the respondent conveyed in his letter dated March 24, 1955. By that order the respondent virtually refused to carry out the directions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent refused to implement superior Tribunal's directions, constituting denial of justice and undermining court hierarchy; JC cannot excuse this by reviewing Tribunal's correctness.

holdings.text: Refusal by subordinate tribunal to carry out directions of superior tribunal is denial of justice and destructive of hierarchy of courts principle.

anchor.surface_text: By that order the respondent virtually refused to carry out the directions which a superior tribunal had given to him in exercise of its appellate powers in respect of an order of assessment made by him. Such refusal is in effect a denial of justice, and is furthermore destructive of one of the basic principles in the administration of justice based as it is in this country on a hierarchy of courts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Leads to chaos in administration of justice; basic principle requires obedience to superior appellate directions.

holdings.text: If a subordinate tribunal refuses to carry out directions given to it by a superior tribunal, the result will be chaos in the administration of justice.

anchor.surface_text: If a subordinate tribunal refuses to carry out directions given to it by a superior tribunal in the exercise of its appellate powers, the result will be chaos in the administration of justice and we have indeed found it very difficult to appreciate the process of reasoning by which the learned Judicial Commissioner while roundly condemning the respondent for refusing to carry out the directions of the superior tribunal,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undermines hierarchical structure essential to justice administration.

holdings.text: The order of the Tribunal dated April 22, 1954, had become final and binding on the parties after withdrawal of reference application.

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that the order of the Tribunal dated April 22, 1954, was not under challenge before the Judicial Commissioner. That order had become final and binding on the parties, and the respondent could not question it in any way.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference under s.66(1) withdrawn, rendering order unchallengeable and binding on inferior authorities.

holdings.text: The Judicial Commissioner was not sitting in appeal over the Tribunal and it was not open to him to say that the order of the Tribunal was wrong.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner was not sitting in appeal over the Tribunal and we do not think that in the circumstances of this case it was open to him to say that the order of the Tribunal was wrong and, therefore, there was no injustice in disregarding that order. As we have said earlier, such view is destructive of one of the basic principles of the administration of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Writ jurisdiction under Art.226 does not permit review of final Tribunal order's merits.

holdings.text: Even if the order of the Tribunal was wrong, a subordinate tribunal could not disregard it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sanctity of hierarchy requires obedience regardless of perceived error, absent proper challenge.

holdings.text: Mandamus under Art.226 lies to compel Income-tax Officer to carry out binding directions of Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The short question for decision is whether the learned Judicial Commissioner of Bhopal rightly dismissed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution made by the Bhopal Sugar Industries, Limited... to compel the Income-tax Officer... to carry-out certain directions given by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enforces public duty to obey final superior orders; JC erred in denying writ despite finding violation.

holdings.text: There is no difficulty in understanding the Tribunal's order directing ascertainment of average transport charges from centers to factory.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direction clear on its face; respondent's misreading unjustified.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the learned Judicial Commissioner was clearly in error in holding that numbermanifest injustice resulted from the order of the respondent companyveyed in his letter dated March 24, 1955. By that order the respondent virtually refused to carry out the directions which a superior tribunal had given to him in exercise of its appellate powers in respect of an order of assessment made by him. Such refusal is in effect a denial of justice, and is furthermore destructive of one of the basic principles in the administration of justice based as it is in this companyntry on a hierarchy of companyrts. If a subordinate tribunal refuses to carry out directions given to it by a superior tribunal in the exercise of its appellate powers, the result will be chaos in the administration of justice and we have indeed found it very difficult to appreciate the process of reasoning by which the learned Judicial Commissioner while roundly companydemning the respondent for refusing to carry out the directions of the superior tribunal, yet held that numbermanifest injustice resulted from such refusal. It must be remembered that the order of the Tribunal dated April 22, 1954, was number under challenge before the Judicial Commissioner.

outcome.relief_summary: Judicial Commissioner's dismissal held erroneous; respondent compelled to carry out Tribunal directions
directions: Respondent to carry out directions of Income-tax Appellate Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: We think that the learned Judicial Commissioner was clearly in error in holding that no manifest injustice resulted from the order of the respondent conveyed in his letter dated March 24, 1955. By that order the respondent virtually refused to carry out the directions

We think that the learned Judicial Commissioner was clearly in error in holding that numbermanifest injustice resulted from the order of the respondent companyveyed in his letter dated March 24, 1955. By that order the respondent virtually refused to carry out the directions which a superior tribunal had given to him in exercise of its appellate powers in respect of an order of assessment made by him. Such refusal is in effect a denial of justice, and is furthermore destructive of one of the basic principles in the administration of justice based as it is in this companyntry on a hierarchy of companyrts. If a subordinate tribunal refuses to carry out directions given to it by a superior tribunal in the exercise of its appellate powers, the result will be chaos in the administration of justice and we have indeed found it very difficult to appreciate the process of reasoning by which the learned Judicial Commissioner while roundly companydemning the respondent for refusing to carry out the directions of the superior tribunal, yet held that numbermanifest injustice resulted from such refusal. It must be remembered that the order of the Tribunal dated April 22, 1954, was number under challenge before the Judicial Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner was not sitting in appeal over the Tribunal and we do not think that in the circumstances of this case it was open to him to say that the order of the Tribunal was wrong and, therefore, there was no injustice in disregarding that order. As we have said earlier, such view is destructive of one of the basic principles of the administration of justice.

We think that the learned Judicial Commissioner was clearly in error in holding that numbermanifest injustice resulted from the order of the respondent companyveyed in his letter dated March 24, 1955. By that order the respondent virtually refused to carry out the directions which a superior tribunal had given to him in exercise of its appellate powers in respect of an order of assessment made by him. Such refusal is in effect a denial of justice, and is furthermore destructive of one of the basic principles in the administration of justice based as it is in this companyntry on a hierarchy of companyrts. If a subordinate tribunal refuses to carry out directions given to it by a superior tribunal in the exercise of its appellate powers, the result will be chaos in the administration of justice and we have indeed found it very difficult to appreciate the process of reasoning by which the learned Judicial Commissioner while roundly companydemning the respondent for refusing to carry out the directions of the superior tribunal, yet held that numbermanifest injustice resulted from such refusal. It must be remembered that the order of the Tribunal dated April 22, 1954, was number under challenge before the Judicial Commissioner.
